fields.descriptive_line: Creamware oval plaque transfer-printed with a half-length portrait of a man, over-painted in a stipple technique in enamel colours.
fields.physical_description: Oval plaque in creamware, transfer-printed with a half- length portrait of a man, over-painted in a stipple technique in enamel colours.
fields.materials_techniques: This plaque is highly unusual in that it appears at first sight to be transfer-printed in imitation of colour-stipple printing, but was proabably transfer-printed in a light black and then over-painted, partly in a stipple technique in enamel colours (true polychrome printing on ceramics was not achieved on a commercial scale until the mid 19th century).
fields.public_access_description:
This fine creamware plaque was probably made in Staffordshire in the 1780s.  The dating is based on the cut of the gentleman's coat, even though the wig he wears is somewhat old-fashioned for the period.  Unfortunately his identity is unknown.
It is a rather unusual object as, although the basic design is transfer-printed, the coloured enamelling appears to have been done by hand, using the miniaturist technique of stippling.  The underlying transfer-printing would have to have been professionally done, whether at a factory or an independent decorator's workshop.  However, it is possible that the enamelling was done by a professional artist rather than a ceramics painter.
fields.credit: Gift of Mrs. Jennifer M. Moody
fields.history_note: This plaque looks as though it could have been painted by a professional portraitist or portrait miniaturist rather than by a ceramics painter. However, the underlying transfer-printing would have to have been professionally done, whether at a factory or an independent decorator's workshop. The sitter is unknown and enquiries at the National Portrait Gallery have drawn a blank. With regards the dating of the plaque based on the portrait the following information was received from Susan North, Curator of Fashion: Dating portraits of the 18th century is always slightly tricky as, once past the age of about 30, they have a distressing tendency to cling to the fashions of their youth for decades! The key elements here are the wig with queue and double curls (old-fashioned), the high-neck, turned down collar on the coat, along with large plain buttons (all quite fashionable). David Allan's The Connoisseurs of 1780-81 comes to mind; indeed the older gentleman on the left is very similarly attired. It's possible that the subject here continued to wear his wig for several more years, so I would say 1780s.
fields.production_note: oval, apparently cut down from a larger plaque
